185963168.review:
An entire year without fresh content in an Early Access game is kind of insulting. I dont mind being patient for more expansive updates, and they have consistently produced one at least once a year. 2024 is the first (so far) that we've been left out to dry, and monthly "Coffeee Diaries" do little to encourage me to expect more than the little I've seen from it so far- when many of them discuss the numerous system overhauls that sound time consuming and sometimes redundant.

While the simulationist elements are core to what makes this game special, I liked the game well enough in the state it was already in to want more. Give us more content, or take it off the steam store until there's playable proof this hasn't been abandoned.

185903007.review: the combat and camera controls are bad, not "hard to get used to" or "you just need practice" they are just awful. there isnt a good tutorial on combat so i spent the majority of my time looking for tutorials on combat. the "campaign" isnt clear at all on how your able to progress and i needed to watch a tutorial on that too. and they included areas in the campaign map where you can fall and lose all your progress. i understand its more or less a rogue like but its annoying spending hours on tutorials and finally reaching a new area on the map only to either fall into a pit and die or be gang raped by enemies.

185764186.review:
I can recommend this game. 

Yes it's been in development for too long.
Nearly 10 years. No full game. Yes. Yes. Yes. 

It's fun. It has good mechanics. A hand-crafted world. 
The writing is strong, even as it is, almost non-existent. 

Small text with foreboding, underlying environmental story-telling. Works great.
Oppressive atmosphere. Puzzles involving physics. 
The game encourages you to pay attention to details and doesn't hold your hand. 

The game is great, 9/10.

People are unhappy due to the lengthy development time and that's understandable.
Developer states he's making this with his "friends", denoting plural.
$160,000 from the kickstarter, minimal of 3 people; Dev + "friends." 

They had funding for 1 year. 2 if they're frugal. And that's assuming they are only 3 people. They're not. 
As of 8 years ago this game was no longer worth developing. But they have continued. 
Yes. They have had sales from Storefronts such as Steam. Yes. Absolutely. 

Overall this is a passion project. Great devs, very communicative and active with the community.

185693528.review: I've been playing this game for almost 10 years and I've yet to see another game like it in all that time or before. It's a little hardcore and there's certainly a learning curve, I played only the practice arena for nearly 2 years before i attempted the campaign (before the main arena existed), but it's an incredibly in-depth and constantly growing game that offers satisfying gameplay on top of teasingly alluding to additions that are to come. Every time i play this game either something new has been added, or i notice something i didn't on my last playthrough. I tell anyone about it who is even mildly interested, and it will forever remain one of my favorites. I love how the devs are true to their ideals and don't just bend to fit the crowd. I genuinely would never run out of positive things to say about this game, so I'll just stop there.

185408596.review:
Ten years. That’s how long we’ve waited for this game to fulfil its ambitious promises. But after a decade of "development," it's painfully clear that Bare Mettle is more interested in endlessly tinkering with their precious game engine than actually delivering the experience we were promised.

What about the core gameplay? It’s still stuck in the same frustrating cycle of clunky controls and rudimentary content. Combat may be physics-driven, but that "innovation" comes at the cost of basic responsiveness. Every action feels like controlling a marionette through molasses. The NPC AI? They’re supposedly "smarter" and more "immersive," according to the wordy monthly dev posts, but mostly they just bumble around and spout stilted, repetitive dialogue.

And don't get me started on the role system. It's been talked about in blog post after blog post, filled with endless jargon about dynamic behaviors and emergent complexity, yet the actual implementation is nothing more than vague, placeholder features. NPCs "might" do something, depending on a thousand invisible variables you can’t influence or even track. At best, the system feels half-baked; at worst, it’s incoherent.

Meanwhile, Bare Mettle brags about how they spent months optimizing their cloth physics or refining a new terrain system (wow new tile textures!!!). Sure, it's impressive they can simulate cloth with "millions of polygons" or overhaul how grass or cracks in tiles interact with lighting, but none of that matters when your players are still waiting to experience the actual game.

The bottom line is this: No one buys a game to marvel at the backend of its engine. They buy games for compelling gameplay, engaging stories, and functional mechanics—none of which Bare Mettle has managed to deliver in ten years. At this point, the game is nothing more than a tech demo wrapped in empty promises.

Unless the developers can break their obsessive cycle of endless technical refinement and focus on finishing a product worth playing, this game will go down as one of the most tragic examples of wasted potential in modern indie development.

184714354.review:
Bought, refunded. Watched some YouTube videos & realised I wasn't exactly playing as it was intended.

Re-bought and dumped 10 hours into the Campaign and 2 hours into the Arena. 

Pros:
- Combat is unique and enjoyable
- Companions are a nice touch - although he died. Using Loyalty to Command 3 people was a nice replacement.
- Skills are actually useful, magic and physical. 
- Maps are well done. Although I didn't realise a few things such as...
(Compass is actually usable if it's in your inventory, it shows a compass icon in the bottom left of your screen.)
(There's 1 more consumable other than the Blue Bottles that buff your character)
- Arena is a nice touch to throw some time into. It's not fantastic, but it's also a good way to learn how to fight. 

Cons:
- I didn't realise the campaign wasn't completely released until I cleared Level 8 and had to google where to go, lol. 
- With how dark the levels are it's hard not to just constantly have the Torch out. (Maybe add a Lantern you can hook onto your belt?
- Companions ALWAYS end up killing one another after bumping into each other. So despite being able to have 3 you're almost better off just have 1 to avoid conflict. 
- The "Save" game isn't well explained. (You can EXIT whenever you want - outside of combat - and you will always be where you EXITED from. You can die multiple times and you will only go unconscious until your health bar is completely consumed by RED. Glowing Blue Bottles will recover your HP to 100% but there's only 1 per level.
- Darren can die. It would be nice if he only went unconscious. Depending on who you are this is a PRO or a CON.
- The Armour system is slightly weird to get used to. It would be nice if there was a display in your inventory for each part of your body that showed it's defence. Sometimes I'm not sure which piece is better if I have to give up another piece to equip it. 

Overall good game and I'd recommend. With how long it's been released, it's definitely unacceptable that a Campaign isn't complete by now but other than that the game is worth playing for the price.

184050768.review:
This is an analysis for future buyers and a feedback for developers.

To potential buyers: 
This is an game that is very different from others because it doesn't stick to conventions and invites you to explore innovative mechanics in a hardcore setting. The focus of the game is exploration and combat. I would say this game is actually 2 games in one. The first game is the story mode (clicking "begin" in the menu screen), a mode focused on exploration with sparse combat: you will be navigating a maze-like building using your intuition, a compass (if you find one) and sometimes a map, trying to find weapons and gear to survive combat and find clues to what is going on. It is very punishing because dying means losing hours of progress. If you like navigation, exploration and combat, this will be a challeging and fun experience. Just note that the game is not complete, yet very playable, without major bugs. I recommend playing in practice mode first to learn the combat and controls, that are definetely not intuitive nor simple.
The second game is the arena. Here you fight several types of combat in an arena and can manage several "gladiators". It is combat focused with a bit of management. 
In general, the game shines for its innovative combat and magic mechanics. It is worth the price, even if it was just the story mode, or just the arena mode.

Feedback for developers:
First, thank you for making this game. I believe you are bringing innovation to the industry. Please keep the good work. I wish more games could bring new mechanics, or twists in old mechanics, as Exanima does. I personally loved the physics based combat and the magic system (thaumaturgy?). I have been searching for for a hardcore physics-based combat system for some years and this one of two games that satisfied me (the other being "we who are about to die"). 
I have two main suggestions:
1. Please add more control options. I struggled a lot with moving with RMB and with switching between combat and walking stances. There were situations on which I took free hits because I took me too long to hit "tab", as my keyboard hand was not on the keyboard after exploring for 30 min with no combat. I believe a control scheme similar to Project Zomboid would greatly benefit your game: RMB activates the combat stance, instead of tab, and, by default letting go of RMB deactivates it. WASD would become the main input for movement. I think this would work better because in combat WASD is already used as the main source of movement and using RMB to activate the combat stance would make transitioning between combat and walking/running. I think controlling the character with WASD is also more precise, there were several situations on which I tripped, fell or kissed a wall because of controlling the character requires the mouse, even after 10 hours of play. Obviously, this would be added as an option and the player, with the current movement control options still available (although I see no advantage to controlling the PC with the mouse).
2. Please use the physics capabilities of the engine to make exploration more interesting and add more challenges. There were many times that I felt rewarded for removing the lid of a crate and removing random garbage from its insides to find valuable loot inside and many times I felt smart overcoming a hole in the ground by moving objects around. This was only possible because I could physically interact with each item. However I feel like this "physicallity" of the game is not fully explored yet. I would like to find fake walls by moving book stands or using magic blasts, more hidden equipment (e.g. under beds) and enemies (e.g. under a bed sheet), put things on fire with lighting blasts, solve physics-based puzzles, and so on. In the current state of the game (Dec of 2024) I feel like everything being interactable is more of a gimmick than something that adds to gameplay.
3. Please add a Thaumaturgy Power to create light. The game is pretty dark and holding a torch limits combat capabilities. Having the power to create light, with obvious costs (continuity slot and focus), benefits (seeing in the dark) and disadvantages (being less stealthy) seems to fit the game perfectly.
4. Please add saving options. I do enjoy hardcore mechanics when they enhance gameplay. I do not think having so few checkpoints in a game with so much focus on exploration enhances gameplay. I felt confused if the focus of the game is having a long-lived character that survives the whole story mode, or several short-lived characters that each contribute to progress, none of them surviving the whole thing (like in Rogue legacy). In the current state of the game dying feels very punishing and adds very little to gameplay. I had to redo a lot of the same things after dying, which made it very repetitive and boring, because I would lose a lot (sometimes hours) of progress. I decided to "save manually" (copying the .rsg file) after feeling discouraged by the death mechanics and that improved the experience for me greatly. On the one hand I think the game would make more sense if there were no checkpoints and dying with a character allowed you to keep some of the loot, experience and progress. On the other hand the game would also make more sense if it had more checkpoints (one at every area and locked door entrance?), a way to save via items (like in "Kingdom Come: Deliverance"), Thaumaturgy, or even in specific places (e.g. shrines). To me, having just a few checkpoints and death being so punishing as it is now is just a way of making players replay the same thing over and over again, which leads to counterproductive frustration. Naturally, this could be an option, with the current death mechanics still available.
I don't know if anyone in the team will read this, but I took the time anyway because I really liked this game, see great potential in it and would like to see it grow and thrive. I only stopped playing due to reaching an invisible wall in the last floor (were I believe will be the entrance to the next floor) and remembering that this is still early access (I don't want to overplay it now to have a fresher experience at launch). I hope you devs take your time to make this the game you really wanted to make and the make it the best it can be.

183847350.review: As a person who loves fantasy RPGs with more difficult combat fighting, this game is quite a pleasant experience. The dark ambiance makes the game exciting followed by the armor and weapons desings. The difficulty of the game makes the player think about every decision when approaching enemy or exploring the areas, specially since the game has little checkpoints and health recovery options. The arena content is a good way to focus on the combat  and offers enough content to develop your team and acquire the best armor pieces to them. Some downsides of this game is that the combat makes this game difficult to understand at the beginning and difficult to master, such learning curve can make a person drop the game if is not patient enough to keep trying; having long checkpoints also can increase the frustration of a player. While the ambience of the game is well stablished, it's lore can improve giving the player more hints about the events happening in the game. Since this game is still an early access is natural to see some incomplete areas, objects that could be usefult but their used is not implemented yet and more. Right now at it's present state I felt like playing a complete game with enough content, considering it's time and the uniqueness of the combat makes this game a good option to try for every player that likes a different challenge and medieval games.

183843939.review:
The greatest mammoth hunting simulator to not have mammoths in it.

To elaborate, Exanima is a game that has developed ludonarrative harmony. If you hang around the arena and ignore the blue bar on the bottom of the screen, you could easily mistake this dark/low fantasy setting with a alternate historical one, meaning that as soon as fantastical elements are introduced, you *feel* how fantastical they are. Your first ogre fight is the moment that this game truly comes together: you and two allies versus a beast which could crush any one of your heads like a grape. Parrying is futile, as the ogre's club will almost certainly knock you down and most likely send you flying into a wall. Your best response is to flank the beast, managing distance and aggression, while chipping it down with polearms (hence "mammoth hunting"). If you do win, you feel heroic, a step above the common man. If you lose, just hope the hit that took you out wasn't lucky enough to kill you.

183841937.review:
Examina is the lovechild of Dark Souls and a drunk physics simulator. Combat? A chaotic dance of flailing limbs and poor decisions. Story? Who knows—I was too busy wrestling with a door. Every encounter is a gamble, where the odds are never in your favor, but at least the ragdoll physics will make you laugh while you lose.

It’s brutal, unforgiving, and weirdly addictive. If you enjoy a challenge and don’t mind your biggest enemy being your own clumsiness, Examina is ready to ruin your day in the best way possible.

183832857.review: Simplesmente uma baita experiência fora da curva, é imprevisível e também frustrante, mas com aquele gostinho de finalmente venci esse desgraçado.

183757492.review: Incrivel jogo, melhor mecanica de combate que ja joguei, pena que é o jogo acabou incompleto pelos devs

183676340.review:
Esse é um jogo de nicho. Um dungeon crawler com um sistema completamente baseado em física. Não há animações pré-setadas para as ações, tudo se comporta de forma mais ou menos realista baseada num sistema de manipulação dos ossos dos modelos 3D e nas regras presentes na engine do jogo. Engine essa que é feita pelos próprios devs, o que é de se elogiar bastante.

Exanima é dividido em dois modos até o presente momento, a campanha principal na qual você é uma pessoa sem memórias explorando uma masmorra povoada por mortos-vivos. Contanto com as próprias habilidades de localização, combate e observação para chegar o mais longe possível nos diversos mapas do jogo. E campanha de combate, no qual você constrói seu personagem lutando em diversos tipos de eventos, manejando seu dinheiro, contratando pessoas para sua companhia de lutadores e tentando não morrer.

Ambos os modos tem uma boa profundidade. Dá pra colocar horas e mais horas e ainda assim não fazer tudo o que o jogo oferece. No momento dessa review eu tenho 10 horas no jogo, o que não foi suficiente pra chegar na metade do segundo nível da campanha principal, e nem perto do nível máximo que seu personagem pode atingir no modo arena.

Dito isso, os controles são a principal coisa que vai afastar os jogadores menos investidos em deixar de lado certas convenções dos jogos e apreender não um, mas dois sistemas de movimentação distintos o suficiente pra que você fique confuso na hora de jogar. 

O primeiro é o sistema de exploração, é basicamente um controle de tanque. Esquerda e direita giram o eixo do seu personagem e pra frente e pra trás movem ele. É estranho de início, mas depois de uma ou duas horas tudo se torna bem natural. Aliado a isso, você pode manipular os objetos do cenário usando o mouse e os botões de movimento, arrastando, levantando, girando, etc. Usando isso para resolver quebra-cabeças, prender inimigos dentro de salas, ou qualquer outra utilidade que você achar pra eles.

O segundo modo é o de combate, na qual o eixo do seu personagem passa a ser controlado pelo seu mouse e os botões de movimento agora fazem o boneco orbitar o ponto em que o mouse está apontado. Junto a essa mudança completa na movimentação, você precisa ativamente influenciar a forma como seu personagem ataca, já que de novo, não há animações pré-setadas. Se o seu mouse faz um arco após dar o input de ataque, o braço do personagem vai seguir esse arco. É difícil de explicar tanto quanto é difícil de apreender ele. Recomendo entrar no modo arena pra obter prática.

Não bastasse essa estranheza em forma de modos de controle, o jogo não possui tutoriais in-game. Ele tem um manual que explica coisas básicas e o menu de controles que diz o que cada botão faz. Mas tirando isso, o jogador que se vire.

E é essa filosofia de o jogador que se vire que guia toda a sua aventura. Quer saber pra qual direção você está indo? Tem uma bussola em alguma saleta perdida. Quer um mapa pra se localizar? Ache. Achou ele? Ótimo! Agora apreende a ler mapas porque não tem qualquer indicador de onde você está nele. O jogo todo é assim, ele vai te colocar nesse mundo e dizer com um sorriso na cara: "Te vira. E a propósito, não morre não porque você vai perder todo o seu progresso."

Não seria justo fazer um review desse jogo sem ressaltar algumas coisas: 1) Esse jogo está em Acesso Antecipado. Há bugs, o sistema de habilidades e Taumaturgias (as magias desse jogo) está incompleto, nem todos os mapas estão disponíveis, falta uma gama considerável de conteúdo a ser implementada e certas coisas precisam ser melhoradas; 2) Exanima não um jogo por si só. Pelas minhas pesquisas, ele é uma pseudo Tech Demo da engine proprietária que a Bare Mettle está desenvolvendo. Originalmente essa engine seria aplicada num outro título chamado Sui Generis, que ainda está para sair, tendo sido prometido a mais de 10 anos e que incluirá todos os sistemas presentes em Exanima; 3) Esse jogo está em desenvolvimento a mais de 10 anos. Isso indica tanto que os devs querem entregar um bom produto final quanto que os updates não são regulares. Há muito conteúdo? Sim, mas não espere atualizações mensais ou algo assim.

No fim, eu recomendo esse jogo. Definitivamente as 2 horas que a Steam te da pra testar um jogo antes de pedir reembolso não são suficientes pra entender bem os sistemas dele. Mas esse jogo, por algum milagre custa menos de 30 reais no momento desse review. Num mundo onde as versões ultimates de jogos AAA chegam a custar absurdos 600 reais (olhando pra você dona Ubisoft), um jogo com tanto conteúdo e por um preço tão acessível é um grande respiro. Ainda que não seja um jogo pra todo mundo.

183613172.review: VERY difficult to learn, but simply amazing in terms of realism and satisfaction once everything clicks.

183556916.review: The game is neat, but it's mostly just okay. I enjoyed it for a bit, and then I kept dying and just got bored. It's bland, colourless, and clumsy to control. There is no tutorial, just a help menu with missing information. The idea is really cool, the setting is intreguing, but I just don't care to play any more of it. Supposedly I've not even left the "tutorial area" but if this is your tutorial and I'm 8 hours in what exactly is going on.
